resources.string: Dolphins deliberately handle pufferfish causing them to release toxins as a defence mechanism. These toxins can be deadly in high doses, but also have a narcotic effect – and are a powerful hallucinogenic, which dolphins appear to enjoy(factanimal.com).

The Pistol Shrimp is capable of snapping its claw shut so rapidly, that it creates a bubble which collapses to produce a sonic blast. The shock wave can reach 230 decibels, also louder than the sound of a gunshot(factanimal.com).
A common garden snail has 14,000 teeth. Their microscoptic teeth are called radula, and some species actually have over 20,000 teeth(animalfact.com)
The Giant Pacific Octopus has 3 hearts, 9 brains and blue blood. They are also able to change their colour and texture to camouflage themselves in a blink of an eye(animalfact.com).

Polar bears have jet black skin under their white fur coats. It helps them absorb heat to keep warm, while the white fur helps provides camouflage in the snowy and icy environment they live(animalfact.com).
Japanese Macaques play with snowballs for fun. These snow monkeys have been observed rolling up snowballs, then pushing them down hills just for the heck of it(animalfact.com)

It is so hard to distinguish between the fingerprints of koalas and humans that even under a microscope it is hard to tell. There are even reported cases of a koala’s fingerprints confusing forensics at crime scenes(animalfact.com).
The shoebill stork can swallow baby crocodiles whole.

A syrian brown bear named Wojtek was brought by polish shoulders while in Iran. He was made an officer so that he was allowed rations and eventually was promoted to corporal. He helped out by carrying boxes of ammunition(animalfact.com).
To scare of predators, this lizard shoots blood out of its eyes(animalfact.com).
